1130418167061237760 [2019-05-20] @visakanv 💜 516 🔁 51
I want more content like this because at some level I feel like if we can all be more honest with each other about all of this, we’d be less exhausted in aggregate. There’s a cognitive “cost” to maintaining social fictions, and comedic truth-telling releases that tension https://t.co/wr9ub3UZut
  [Quoting Tweet 1130374688792809473 (missing)]

1238038427850772480 [2020-03-12] @visakanv 💜 227 🔁 6
Going through my old photos - it’s striking how much better I looked 2 months after leaving my job. I *wasn’t* eating better, I was eating junk every day. I wasn’t sleeping better, I was playing video games late into the night. I believe this is largely just lower cortisol levels https://t.co/DSqUBXyw3H
↓

https://t.co/1sr9lwAfEr
  [Quoting @visakanv: Nice  Here’s my #1 rec for @twitter: realize that quote tweets are a killer feature of your product. Add it as a separate part of notifications besides All and Mentions. thing I've long pondered: if you go on reddit for eg, you'll find that there are people who are able to write *superb* critiques of tv shows. and I always wonder, how come these people don't just... write for the tv shows? and my sense is that these ppl are feral creatures

this is also kind of why– I think this is genuinely true– some of the best thinkers are anarchist garbageman and schizo monarchist. modern diogenes gang, tbh. we can fantasize about having the best of both worlds, but in practice it's very rare 
 
https://t.co/TyybKoQmkA https://t.co/nKntIvwxfj
  [Quoting @visakanv: Filters have almost never filtered for talent, they’ve almost always filtered for professionalism, ie the ability to maintain an image of civility. Talent often has the essence of barbarism about it https://t.co/dUkPAEdGZ1]

rating.reasoning_summary: This strand is a multi-year meditation on the 'Treehouse Guy' archetype—a viral tweet by @imbethmccoll (2020) that crystallized a counterintuitive sexual/romantic truth: that unbothered, low-status, non-conformist men often provide transcendent experiences. The boundary object is the original tweet itself, which becomes a recurring meme/reference point. The arc is *iterative rather than evolutionary*—the community repeatedly returns to this idea across 5+ years, applying it to new contexts (unemployment-cortisol hypothesis, sex positivity discourse, Buddhist saints, rationalist orgy culture). It's more of a 'sustained riff' than a dialectical refinement, though it does spawn useful sub-concepts like 'treehouse energy' and 'surreal unbotheredness.' High cohesion (same core users), medium utility (provides vocabulary for a real phenomenon but doesn't build new frameworks).

essential_tweets.annotation: The Origin: Beth McColl's viral 'treehouse guy' tweet defining the archetype
The Follow-up: Expanding the absurdist detail ('cereal out of a saucepan')
Visa's First Application: Linking to unemployment-cortisol hypothesis
M_ashcroft Testing: Attempting to validate the theory empirically
Intellectual Extension: Applying the meme to 'feral genius' discourse
Theoretical Deepening: 'Surreal unbotheredness' as the mechanism
Real-World Validation: Univrsw3th4rt's boyfriend embodying the archetype
Community Inventory: Strangestloop soliciting examples of treehouse guys
Rationalist Integration: Yudkowsky's sex-optimization discourse as parallel
Cross-Cultural Mapping: Buddhist 'divine madman' as historical treehouse guy
